title: Lady Gaga’s gruelling post-show ice baths would put an athlete to shame
text:
Lady Gaga goes hardcore after shows (Picture: Instagram)

When it comes to putting on shows and recording new music, Lady Gaga doesn’t do things by half.

So we should have expected her post-show routine to be just as gnarly.

The 33-year-old has revealed that, much like an athlete, she opts for ice baths after her concerts to speed up recovery.

Gaga – real name Stefani Germanotta – told her Instagram followers that she does a ‘hard workout and galactic laps’ to prepare for her Enigma residency in Las Vegas.

But after the show, the real pain kicks in.

The Bad Romance singer explained: ‘Post show routine: ice bath for 5-10 min, hot bath for 20, then compression suit packed with ice packs for 20’ – and she added picture evidence for each step.

Ouch.

Ice baths are beloved by athletes for easing muscle pain, reducing inflammation and improving quality of sleep, while following them up with a hot bath (contrast water therapy) provides relief for muscle soreness.

Meanwhile, the Normatec compression suit favoured by Gaga utilises compression to restrict blood vessels, thus reducing swelling.

We’re guessing this regime came in handy after Gaga’s epic fall last week.

Gaga’s show is very full-on (Picture: Kevin Mazur/Getty Images for Park MGM Las Vegas)

The Applause singer suffered a brutal fall during her Las Vegas residency after she and a fan tumbled off stage.

Gaga had her legs wrapped around the male fan when he appeared to lose his footing, causing both of them to crash into the pit with force.

The A Star Is Born actress continued on with the show, and later joked that she had to undergo a full body X-ray.

Sharing a mock X-ray of a hand making an OK sign, she wrote: ‘When they have to X-Ray almost your entire body…Just Dance. Gonna be ok.’

Thank goodness for that.

As well as dealing with the symptoms of her gruelling gigs, Gaga lives with the chronic pain condition fibromyalgia, and was prevented touring Europe two years ago due to the condition, which causes aching muscles and fatigue.

The newly single star previously told Vogue: ‘Chronic pain is no joke. And it’s every day waking up not knowing how you’re going to feel.’
